lines: A couple of your friends have convinced someone to purchase a bottle of very cheap wine. They are excited about the idea of getting drunk. You are in the basement of a friend's house.
*selectable_if (false) #ACT LIKE YOU ARE DRINKING THE WINE, BUT DON'T
#ACT LIKE YOU ARE DRINKING THE WINE, BUT DON'T
There is one 12-ounce bottle of wine to be distributed among 15 girls. You take a few sips. What do you feel?
With the amount of wine you have just had, you can only ACT drunk (which is precisely what a lot of adolescents do in situations like this). It becomes a contest for who can act the most drunk.

Jean stuffs some socks into her bra and makes believe she's Trisha Lane. Barb does an imitation of Mr. Johnson, the biology teacher who wears the same clothes three weeks in a row, and everyone gets hysterical over it.
Julie and Karen sit next to one another and do an imitation of Mark and Linda slobbering all over one another on the school bus. The next day everyone acts like they are sooooo hung over.
#STUFF SOME SOCKS INTO YOUR BRA AND MAKE BELIEVE YOU ARE TRISHA LANE
#DO AN IMITATION OF MR. JOHNSON, THE BIOLOGY TEACHER, WHO WEARS HIS PANTS UP AROUND HIS ARMPITS
#GET KAREN AND DO AN IMITATION OF MARK AND LINDA SLOBBERING ALL OVER ONE ANOTHER ON THE SCHOOL BUS
Everyone gets a big kick out of what you did, and they all laugh hysterically about it. The next day you become a star for being "wasted" and doing stupid things.
You are usually not as impulsive as this, so I guess a litle silliness won't hurt. This experience does nothing negative to you.

This kind of impulsive behavior is becoming your trademark. You are developing a style that is characterized by clowning around to gain attention. It works great and will continue to work great as an adolescent, but as an adult it may
lead you down a path of self-destruction.

The attention you get for clowning around is so satisfying that you will stop at nothing to get more. The bra thing was funny. The Mr. Johnson routine was hysterical. The "face-sucking" exhibition was so funny that Marissa falls back
and her hits head on the wall.

This, of course, brings her mother flying down the stairs only to discover all of you and the wine. You beg her not to tell your mother but it does absolutely no good. You are grounded for three weeks, and NO TV.
Of course you feel perfectly normal. Not even a young child could get tipsy on two sips of wine.
But a kid like you can get caught drinking when Marissa's mother spies on you, and reports back to your mother. You are grounded for a month.
Many of your friends act goofy, but you will probably just sit around watching them and laughing.

Your concern over what your friends might think of you, combined with the fear of getting caught drinking, causes you to act in a very peculiar way when you get home. Even though you are not drunk, Mom suspects that "something funny is
going on here." Even though you haven't taken enough to be drunk, your breath still smells.
#DO NOTHING AND HOPE FOR THE BEST
This just about seals your fate. Your behavior is a dead giveaway. You are accused of hanging around with a no-good bunch of derelicts and grounded for a week.
Your mother doesn't feel like she has enough evidence to convict you, but for the next three days she asks you a hundred questions like, "Do any of your friends in school drink?"
She is disappointed in you, but more understanding than you would think. She thanks you for telling the truth.
Your Familial sphere score is low, suggesting conflicts at home right now. Your mother tries to be understanding, but comes off as a nag.
#JUST LISTEN TO HER AND KEEP YOUR MOUTH SHUT

You can't justify this kind of behavior to your family; it was WRONG. They don't want to hear why you thought it was O.K. to do it. They want to hear why it was NOT O.K., and why you won't do it again.
Good idea. Regardless of your excuse, it won't work. Intellectual sphere rises because of good common sense.

Failure to conform to peer pressure makes you emotionally stronger but pulls you outside of this peer group. Your Social status suffers, but sometimes that is the price you pay for being an independent free-thinking person.
Most of your friends are probably doing the same thing. That's probably why it is taking three hours to finish 12 ounces of wine. After the wine is finally finished, you can:
